title-group.article-title: Preparation and phase composition optimization of yttrium silicates/SiC multilayer coating coated carbon/carbon composites

contrib-group.aff: 1Key Laboratory of Auxiliary Chemistry & Technology for Light Chemical Industry, Ministry of Education, Shaanxi University of Science & Technology, Xi’an Shaanxi, China.
2The 8th Oil Production Plant of Petrol China Changqing Oil Field Company, P.R. China.

author-notes.corresp: Wang Ya-qin, Key Laboratory of Auxiliary Chemistry & Technology for Light Chemical Industry, Ministry of Education, Shaanxi University of Science & Technology, Xi’an Shaanxi, 710021, China Email: wangyaqinheart@yahoo.com.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In order to optimize the phase composition and improve the oxidation resistance of yttrium silicates coating, Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12 coatings with different phase composition were deposited on the surface of SiC pre-coated carbon/carbon (C/C) composites using a hydrothermal electrophoretic deposition process. The as-prepared multilayer coatings were characterized by X-ray diffractometer (XRD) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The influence of phase composition on the morphologies and anti-oxidation properties of the multicomposition yttrium silicates coatings were investigated. The phase composition of the coating was optimized. Results show that Y2SiO5/Y2Si2O7/Y4Si3O12 mass ratio has strong effect on the morphology and oxidation resistance of yttrium silicates coatings. It is found that a low thermal expansion coefficient (CTE) district existed in the Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12 ternary phase diagram. When the optimized phase composition of Y2SiO5/Y2Si2O7/Y4Si3O12 in the low CTE district reaches Y2SiO5 = 20.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 8.3 wt%, and Y4Si3O12 = 71.6 wt%, dense and homogenous yttrium silicates coatings with perfect oxidation resistance are achieved. After 80 h oxidation in 1773 K, weight loss of the coated C/C composites is only 2.17 × 10−3 g.cm−2.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Carbon/carbon composite (C/C) as one of the most promising materials for high-temperature applications are being widely used in a variety of aerospace and ground-based applications due to their excellent high temperature mechanical properties and good thermal shock resistance. However, their oxidation above 673 K limits their applications in oxygen-containing atmosphere at high temperature.1–3 Therefore, many coating systems for oxidation protection of C/C composites have been exploited.4–8

SiC coatings are widely used as bonding and buffer layer because of their good high temperature physical and chemical adaptability to C/C composites. However, monolayer SiC coating cannot protect C/C for long time at high temperature. To solve this problem, the application of mixture phases with Y2SiO5, Y2Si2O7, and Y4Si3O12 is essential to ensure the mechanical stability of the coating due to their high melting and equivalentthermal expansion coefficient (CTE) to SiC.9–11 However, the multicomposition coating has different CTE when the phase composition is different. The mismatch of CTE between inner and outer layer may lead to some cracks in the coating, through which oxygen can attack C/C substrate. Finally, the oxidation-resistant performance of multilayer coating is decreased. So, the optimized phase composition of yttrium silicates seems to be very important. To date, there are no reports about research on phase composition of Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12 coating.

In the present work, the phase composition of Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12 was designed and optimized on the basis of the previous research in order to improve the anti-oxidation property of yttrium silicates coatings. The relations of CTE and phase composition were calculated. Moreover, an optimized dense and homogeneous Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12 oxidation-resistant coating was prepared on SiC-C/C composites surface by a hydrothermal electrophoretic deposition process. The influence of phase composition on the microstructure and oxidation-protective ability of multicomposition yttrium silicates coatings was particularly investigated.

sec.title: Synthesis of yttrium silicates nano-crystallites
sec.p: Y (NO3)3, Na2SiO3, and NaOH were selected as main source materials. Three kinds of yttrium silicates nano-crystallites (mol ratio of Y: Si: O = 2:1:5, 2:2:7, and 4:3:12) prepared from different initial solution compositions were achieved by a sonochemical method. Details of the preparation are reported in reference 12.

sec.title: Hydrothermal electrophoretic deposition
sec.p: Small specimens (10 mm × 10 mm × 10 mm) were cut from bulk CVI 2D-C/C composites with a density of 1.72 g/cm3 to be used as cathode substrates. Then they were hand-polished with 340, 600, and 1000 grit SiC paper, cleaned with isopropanol for 10 min, and dried at 333 K for 1 h in an oven. The preparation details of the SiC bonding layer by pack cementation are reported in reference 13. The hydrothermal electrophoretic deposition process was prepared as follows: First, the sonochemical-resulted yttrium silicates nano-powders (Y2SiO5, Y2Si2O7 and Y4Si3O12) were mixed and dispersed in isopropanol with sonication for 30 min and a later magnetic stirring for 24 h. Second, 0.06 g/L crystalline analytical reagent iodine as charging agent was added to the above suspension, and the mixture was subjected to sonication and magnetic stirring for 12 h. Third, the as-prepared suspension solution was put into a hydrothermal autoclave, which was heated in a furnace with the voltage kept at 210 V and the temperature kept at 393 K. After 20 min deposition, the autoclave was taken out and cooled down naturally. Subsequently, the specimen was taken out from the autoclave and dried at 333 K in air for 4 h. Finally, the Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12–coated SiC-C/C composites were obtained.

Based on the previous works,14,15 the optimized mass compositions of yttrium silicates coatings with two phase composition were Y2SiO5/Y2Si2O7 = 3:7, Y2SiO5/Y4Si3O12 = 1:3, Y2Si2O7/Y4Si3O12 = 1:9, phase composition of multilayer coatings contain Y2SiO5, Y2Si2O7, and Y4Si3O12 three phases were designed and shown in Figure 1. Figure 1.
Phase composition of the designed multilayer coatings. (a) Y2SiO5 = 52.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 21.8 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 26.1 wt%. (b) Y2SiO5 = 64.4 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 4.0 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 31.6 wt%. (c) Y2SiO5 = 20.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 8.3 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 71.6 wt%.

sec.title: Measurements of the coated C/C composites
sec.p: The crystallites structures of coatings were measured by Rigaku D/max-3 C X-ray diffraction (XRD). The morphologies of multicoating were analyzed by JSM-6400 scanning electronic microscope (SEM). The isothermal oxidation tests of the as-coated samples were carried out in an electrical furnace at 1773 K in air. When the test temperature was reached, the specimens were put into the furnace and rapidly heated to the temperature. The specimens were weighted at room temperature before and after the thermal treatment by an electronic balance with a sensitivity of ±0.1 mg. The data were collected every 1 h on eight samples and the average weight changes were reported as a curve of weight loss vs. time.

sec.title: Results and discussion
sec.p:
Figure 2 shows the XRD spectra of the powders prepared by the sonochemical process with different initial solution compositions. It shows that strong peak of Y2SiO5, Y2Si2O7, and Y4Si3O12 at 30°~50° can be observed, which indicates that nearly pure mono phase Y2SiO5, Y2Si2O7, and Y4Si3O12 crystallites are obtained, though a little Y2O3 phase is detected in the Y2SiO5 crystallites. Figure 2.
X-ray diffractometer (XRD) spectra of Y2Si2O7 and Y2SiO5 powders prepared by sonochemical process.

Figure 3 shows the surface SEM images of Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12 coatings prepared according to phase composition shown in Figure 1. There is some visible propagation of cracks in the surface of yttrium silicates coating when the phase composition is a (Figure 3(a)). Cracking of the coating surface is obviously improved and decreased number of cracks when the phase composition reaches b (Figure 3(b)), especially when the phase composition is c, very dense and homogeneous multilayer coatings with no micro-cracks are obtained (Figure 3(c)). Different surface structures of multilayer coatings may result from the thermal stress caused by the CTE mismatch between Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12 outer layer and SiC inner layer.16 CTE of Y2SiO5, Y2Si2O7, and Y4Si3O12 are 6.9 × 10−6K−1, 3.9 × 10−6K−1, and 4.31 × 10−6K−1, respectively, according to work of Sun Ziqi.17 By calculation, CTE of the multicomposition coating shown in Figure 4 can be derived as 5.50 × 10−6 K−1, 5.95 × 10−6 K−1, and 4.80 × 10−6 K−1 for the composition of a, b, and c. Figure 3.
Surface scanning electron microscopy (SEM) morphologies of yttrium silicates coatings deposited with different phase composition. (a) Y2SiO5 = 52.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 21.8 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 26.1 wt%. (b) Y2SiO5 = 64.4 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 4.0 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 31.6 wt%. (c) Y2SiO5 = 20.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 8.3 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 71.6 wt%. Figure 4.
Relation of thermal expansion coefficient with different phase composition (thermal expansion coefficient (CTE): × 10−6 K−1). (a) Y2SiO5 = 52.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 21.8 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 26.1 wt%. (b) Y2SiO5 = 64.4 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 4.0 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 31.6 wt%. (c) Y2SiO5 = 20.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 8.3 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 71.6 wt%.

It indicates that there is a low thermal expansion district in Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12 ternary phase diagram shown in Figure 4. Compared with phase composition a and b, CTE of coating of c phase composition is more similar to that of SiC bonding layer (4.5 × 10−6 K−1), which may result in the good combination between the outer coating and SiC bonding layer. According to the theories of Hwang and Fergus,18 the matching of CTE main influences existing state of thermal stress between coating and matrix in ceramic fiber-reinforced composite silicon-silicon-oxygen composite materials. The CTE of outer layer should be as close as possible to the matrix, which may reduce cracking of coatings caused by thermal stress. The result is entirely correspondent with the above SEM analyses shown in Figure 3.

The cross-section SEM microstructure of Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12 coatings on SiC-C/C composites prepared with different phase composition is shown in Figure 5. An obvious two-layer multicoating is observed. It is clear that some penetrating cross cracks internal and external coating are existent (shown in Fig.5a) when the phase composition is a, which may result from the thermal stress caused by the marked CTE mismatch between yttrium silicates outer layer and SiC inner layer. When the phase composition is b, not only the cracking between internal and external coating decrease (Figure 5(b)) but also the coating becomes dense and homogeneous. A denser and more uniform Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12 coating is achieved when the phase composition is c. These are also well in accordance with the surface SEM analyses. Similar CTE between outer layer and SiC inner layer may reduce generation of internal stress in the coating for an integrated coating obtained. Figure 5.
Cross-section scanning electron microscopy (SEM) microstructures of yttrium silicates coatings deposited with different phase composition. (a) Y2SiO5 = 52.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 21.8 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 26.1 wt%. (b) Y2SiO5 = 64.4 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 4.0 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 31.6 wt%. (c) Y2SiO5 = 20.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 8.3 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 71.6 wt%.

Figure 6 shows the isothermal oxidation curves of the coated C/C samples in air at 1773 K. It reveals that the weight loss of SiC-coated C/C composites will reach 19.33 × 10−3g.cm−2 after 5 h oxidation in air at 1773 K, which infers that single SiC coating cannot effectively protect C/C composites from oxidation because of the porous structure. However, the prepared yttrium silicates/SiC coating exhibits better oxidation resistance, which can effectively protect C/C in air at 1773 K for 80 h. But it is also found that the coated C/C composite reaches almost 4.29 × 10−3 g.cm−2 weight loss within 25 h in air at 1773 K when the phase composition is a. After oxidation in air at 1773 K for 25 h, the weight loss rate of the sample increases rapidly with time. This may be due to the cracked microstructures of the coatings shown in Figures 3(a) and 5(a). Figure 6.
Isothermal oxidation curves of the coated samples at 1773 K in air. (a) Y2SiO5 = 52.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 21.8 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 26.1 wt%. (b) Y2SiO5 = 64.4 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 4.0 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 31.6 wt%. (c) Y2SiO5 = 20.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 8.3 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 71.6 wt%.

The weight loss of Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12-coated C/C composites reveals a similar linear increase within certain time. According to Wagner’s19 high-temperature oxidation theory, it is not an effective protection for the coating when the oxidation weight loss as a function of time accord with linear rule, which is controlled by the rate of oxygen diffusion along the pores, holes, micro-cracks, and grain boundary of the multilayer coating. Therefore, the oxidation resistant performance of the coated C/C depends on the crack dimension in the coating, which will be determined by difference of CTE between inner and outer layer. These cracks may provide channels for oxygen to attack the C/C substrate and result in the oxidation weight loss of the coated C/C. The oxidation resistance is improved when the coating composition reaches b, which may relate to the decrease in cracks (Figure 3(b)) and no penetrative cracks in cross-section of the coating (Figure 5(b)). While the phase composition is c, the oxidation resistance of the coated C/C is remarkably improved. After 80 h oxidation in 1773 K, the weight loss of the coated sample is only 2.17 × 10−3 g.cm−2, which indicates the achievement of excellent anti-oxidation property of the multilayer coatings. It can be deduced that the oxidation protection ability of Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12 coating is determined by difference of CTE between inner and outer layer.

Figure 7 shows the surface SEM images of the prepared coatings after oxidation in air at 1773 K for 80 h. During the isothermal oxidation test process, the quickly cooling down of the sample from 1773 K to room temperature may result in some micro-cracks of the external coating. According to Webster’s research,20 the oxygen will diffuse into the interface of the coatingthrough these defects and reach the surface of SiC inner layer, where the oxygen will react with SiC and yttrium silicates, which results in the generation of SiO2, CO, and CO2 gases. Clearly, smooth glass layers are formed on the surface of the coating shown in Figure 7(a), (b), and (c). The oxidation reaction is shown in Equations (1)–(3). (1) (2) (3) Some holes are also observed on the surface of the coatings (Figure 7(a) and (b)), which may generate from the escape of the oxidation gases. In addition, some penetrating cross cracks can be found on the coating surface from Figure 7(a), it may result from the mismatch of CTE between the yttrium silicates outer-layer and the SiC bonding layer. These cracks might not be self-sealed because the fluidity of the SiO2 glass is poor and rapid evaporation at 1673 K. Carbon matrix may be oxidized by oxygen diffusing through the penetrating cross cracks, which leads to the failure of the coating. Compared with Figure 7(a), the crack size of the coating shown in Figure 7(b) obviously decreases. Especially in Figure 7(c), a dense, homogeneous, and crack-free Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12 coating is achieved, which well agrees with the above analysis results about CET between outer and inner layer. Figure 7.
Surface scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the prepared coatings deposited with different phase composition after oxidation in air at 1773 K for 85 h. (a) Y2SiO5 = 52.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 21.8 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 26.1 wt%. (b) Y2SiO5 = 64.4 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 4.0 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 31.6 wt%. (c) Y2SiO5 = 20.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 8.3 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 71.6 wt%.

Figure 8 shows the cross-section SEM images of the prepared coatings after oxidation in air at 1773 K for 80 h. Clearly, big holes formed owing to the oxidation of C/C are found in C/C matrix near a penetrating cross crack shown in Figure 8(a). Therefore, the weight loss of the coated C/C sample is primarily due to the formation of cracks and holes in the coating. Compared with Figure 8(a), no obvious holes but some micro-cracks are found near the coating shown in Figure 8(b) and (c). This result is well in accord with the anti-oxidation properties shown in Figure 6. According to research of Webster,21 yttrium silicates exhibit high melting point (about 1973 K), which ensures a good chemical stability between SiC at 1873 K. Thus, no chemical reaction will be made between internal and external layer, which guarantees excellent anti-oxidation properties of the multicomposition coating. Figure 8.
Cross-section scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images of the prepared coatings deposited with different phase composition after oxidation in air at 1773 K for 85 h. (a) Y2SiO5 = 52.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 21.8 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 26.1 wt%. (b)Y2SiO5 = 64.4 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 4.0 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 31.6 wt%. (c) Y2SiO5 = 20.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 8.3 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 71.6 wt%.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A hydrothermal electrophoretic deposition technique has been found to provide a simple and economic route for the preparation of dense and homogeneous yttrium silicates coatings on SiC pre-coated C/C composites.

Based on the above research, it is observed that Y2SiO5/Y2Si2O7/Y4Si3O12 mass ratio has strong influence on the microstructure and oxidation-resistant performance of yttrium silicates coatings. A low CTE district is existed in the Y2SiO5-Y2Si2O7-Y4Si3O12 ternary phase diagram. When the optimized phase composition of Y2SiO5/Y2Si2O7/Y4Si3O12 in the low CTE district reaches Y2SiO5 = 20.1 wt%, Y2Si2O7 = 8.3 wt%, Y4Si3O12 = 71.6 wt%, dense and uniform yttrium silicates coatings with the best anti-oxidation property are achieved. After 80 h oxidation in 1773 K, weight loss of the coated C/C composites is only 2.17 × 10−3 g.cm−2.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: The present work was supported by the National Natural Science Foundation of China [grant number 51012108], Foundation of New Century Excellent Talent in University of China [grant number NCET-06-0893], Doctorate Research Foundation of SUST [grant number 20070708001], and Graduate Innovation Foundation of SUST.
